[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Sel√ªnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out.
Isobel: You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume?
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Sel√ªnite.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Sel√ªne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*

Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: Why did you summon me here?
Gale: I wanted to see you. While I still could.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: It's a heavy burden, yes - but one you're able for. Think of the good your sacrifice will do.
Gale: I am trying. Believe me, I am. The path is set, and I will not stray from it - even as my heart quakes.
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: Why are you so sure it's inevitable? We haven't even found this 'Heart of the Absolute' yet.
Gale: I can feel it - ever since we set foot in this strange, corrupted land. The closer we get, the heavier my own heart becomes.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: What do you have in mind?
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: It's breathtaking, Gale. Is this starry sky your doing?
Gale: Indeed. The curse is still present of course - just veiled and at arm's length for now. Not a trick I can repeat often, but tonight? Tonight is different.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: I refuse to believe this is the end. We'll find another way, I promise.
Gale: Thank you. But even if we do find another way, perhaps this is the right way. The end fate wishes for me.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: How thoughtful. And where did you find this friend?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: She's telling the truth. She didn't know.
Sazza: I told ya! I was tryin' to follow orders best I could!
Nightwarden Minthara: Silence, wretch. And remember - you owe your miserable life to this one.
Sazza: I won't cause any more trouble - I swears it.
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: You seem especially philosophical this evening. Are you all right?
Gale: I will be, soon. I am perhaps just one hard day away from being without any troubles at all.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: I refuse to believe this is the end. We'll find another way, I promise.
Gale: Thank you. But even if we do find another way, perhaps this is the right way. The end fate wishes for me.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Wyll: End her now, or she'll be cursing new victims by sundown.

Player: Give me power - the more, the better.

Gale: Please - this has gone on long enough.
Gale: I was quite clear about the imperative nature of my request to you, and despite that  I've seen neither hair nor hind of a magic artefact.
Gale: Already, I've allowed myself to go untreated for too long. I fear it's already too late - I've no choice but to depart this company of ours, and pray I find something for myself.
Player: Oh, you're still here?

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*

Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: I'm afraid all of this is just a fantasy.
Gale: So it is. But a very fine one.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning?
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Minthara steps up on the stone tower outside the gate to the Druid Grove, she assumes her imposing posture, arms at her back, she locks gaze with the player
Asharak: If I don't see you after the battle... tell the children I took out the drow.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The archer nocks another arrow, when the army arrives beneath Minthara and lowers the bow to watch
Asharak: Get that damn gate closed!
Asharak: This is it, people. Weapons ready, eyes to the front.
Asharak: Anyone who takes down a worg gets their choice of cut tonight...
Asharak: By Amaunator's Eternal Sun, none of us are dying today!
Narrator: *A splinter of ice works its way into your mind.*
Nightwarden Minthara: A pretty speech. It almost brings a tear to my eye.
NodeContext: amused, referring to the tiefling leaders inspiring speech to the defenders but talking to the player
Nightwarden Minthara: Now slit his throat, and open that gate. The Absolute wants all of them dead.
NodeContext: simple, to the point - killing is a very ordinary thing to her
Player: Obey and open the gate.

Orin: Loosen the bonds, sweet meat. Bhaal does not crave the taste of bait on his altar.
NodeContext: Mocking the player  for saving their companion - it was never about them
Orin: No trust in my promises, but I smell the tyrant's corpse-reek. You are steeped in his rot.
Orin: See how good I was? How patient while you drained the tyrant's juices for me?
Orin: I left the blood inside, the pelt unskinned. But I had such plans for this one, and the blade was made to slice...
NodeContext: Longing, playful - on the cusp of unleashhing her violence. All refering to the victim on the slab, but speaking to the player
Player: Go ahead. I won't stop you.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: Keep quiet.
Sazza: You coulda told me who you woz!
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A duergar? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: All right. Expect me at the grove.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: It's breathtaking, Gale. Is this starry sky your doing?
Gale: Indeed. The curse is still present of course - just veiled and at arm's length for now. Not a trick I can repeat often, but tonight? Tonight is different.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning?
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You sound sure in your course of action then.
Gale: Resigned to it, rather. But that is not to say I am without fear. Far from it.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'm not going anywhere, Gale. I'll be by your side, whatever dawn brings.
Gale: Yes... but there is so much to live for, and so few moments in which to house it all.
Gale: Damn you. Damn you for giving me so much to care about. Our friends, our adventures... this would have been so much easier if it was just me. But it isn't.
Gale: If there is a way - any way - to save all that's grown dear to me, I want to seize it. I just can't fathom what that might be, other than to fail Mystra and condemn the world.
Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Gale: Stay with me, will you? I don't want to think of it any more, but I don't want to be alone either.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

Sazza: Mistress! It's me, yer loyal servant, Sazza. I'm back - an' I brought a friend.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drow? Tell me, Sazza, did your misadventures take you to the Underdark?
Sazza: They woz in some rickety druid grove! Mostly full of tieflin's, but them intruders you're after were hidin' out there!
Nightwarden Minthara: I presume you dealt with my prey, and massacred the rest?
Sazza: Ah... well, the thing about that is... they sorta massacred us.
Sazza: This mug helped me escape though. I say we stick a few holes in them... show how grateful we are.

Narrator: *You feel a cold hand caress your mind as the drow appraises you.*
Nightwarden Minthara: Oh dear. Your prisoner is one of the Absolute's favourites, Sazza. A True Soul.
Sazza: Nah. Can't be... they woz in the grove, hangin' around with the tieflin's.
Nightwarden Minthara: Undercover, no doubt. Carrying out the Absolute's will. Oh, Sazza - you have made a grave error.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it will be your last. My spiders are hungry, little one...
Nightwarden Minthara: ...but before they feast, tell me where that grove is, and I may yet spare your life.
Sazza: It's past the bridge, to the east! Big ol' gate, covered in ivy! Don't hurt me, mistress. Please!
Nightwarden Minthara: I will not hurt you. My spiders will have that pleasure.
Sazza: No! I mucked up, I'm sorry! But I didn't know who they woz... they didn't tell me nothin'!
Player: You only have to look at me to know I'm your superior, wretch.
Sazza: Somebody help!
Nightwarden Minthara: Through sheer luck, that pathetic worm has brought me the information I need.
Nightwarden Minthara: And it seems that the inhabitants of the grove trust you - we can use that against them.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have a part to play in this slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Return to the grove. When my raiding party approaches, throw open the gate and signal me.
Narrator: *The fate of the grove's inhabitants hangs in the balance.*
Narrator: *Killing the drow here would spare them, but it might be better to face her warband at the grove itself, on familiar ground.*
Narrator: *On the other hand, participating in the slaughter as she asks may be the perfect way to earn her trust, and access to the cult's inner circle.*
Player: I want no part of this.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates and crush our enemies.
Player: And I'm happy to do it - for a price.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up on  the player arriving in a secluded grove.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Gale gestures, summoning purple, pink, green and yellow will-o'-the-wisps (effects only), basking the scene in a mysterious glow.

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.

Gale is sitting on the ground, looking up at a spectacular night sky streaked with aurora borealis. (This is an effect that will be used in the spell teaching scene as well.)

Despite being somewhere in the shadow cursed lands, Gale is painting a magical picture that silently attests to his magical prowess. The player approaches Gale and sits down next to him.
Gale: I love this time of night.
NodeContext: Wistful
Gale: There's an almost reverent silence that accompanies the peak of darkness, when you'd almost believe the dawn will never break.
Gale: The cradle of eternity.
Gale: The timelessness of lovers.
Gale: That most beautiful of fantasies.
Player: Why did you summon me here?
Gale: I wanted to see you. While I still could.
Gale: This may be my last night alive. I wanted it to be under a canopy of beauty and wonder...
Gale: ...and with company to match.
NodeContext: Full of longing
Gale: I thought this place might bring me peace. I thought it might make the weight of what I must do feel a little lighter... but I am not so sure.
Player: Is this truly what you want, to die for the promise of Mystra's forgiveness?
Gale: Babe or crone, coward or hero, death is assured. Mystra's forgiveness is not. If you knew the end was near, would you not want to ensure it had meaning?
Gale: I am terrified - I will not claim otherwise. My face could scarcely conceal it even if my words sought to deny it.
Gale: There is no point in running from the inevitable. Better to meet it, on my own terms.
Player: You're right. At least this way, you might take the Absolute down with you.
Gale: I can only hope that there are few innocents within the Absolute's reach, when the time comes... and that you will seek safety, far away from me.
Gale: Stay with me a while, will you? Day will come all too soon, even in this place.
Player: I'd rather not listen to you wallowing in self-pity. Good night, Gale.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1)
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Lae'zel: A simple trade? More deception. Take her head.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Such power will let me better serve the Spider Queen. Give it to me.
Player: Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Narrator: *You stand before the mysterious mace once more.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*

Gale: Are you quite sure that's wise?
Shadowheart: We should leave that thing and just get out of here while we can.

Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.*
Narrator: *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.*
Narrator: *Taking this mace would surely lead to something quite disastrous.*
Narrator: *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Claim the mace and delight in its danger.

Apprentice Laridda: Quiet, Lunkbug. The walls have ears.
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: I'm a friend - Thulla sent me.
Apprentice Laridda: Glittering gods - she actually survived...?
Lunkbug: Praise Ironhand. Laridda - our prayers are answered!
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: Leave the True Soul to me. Now tell me what you know.
Apprentice Laridda: Lunkbug, don't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Wyll: The trapped gnomes won't last forever. We've got to help.
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm going to punish her - throughly.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: Blood taints all our hands in ways we never predict.
Madeline: But - but this wasn't supposed to happen - I swear!
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Keep going.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours?
Gale: Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.
Gale: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present.
Gale: If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: This is no ordinary artefact, Gale. Do this and you'd challenge the gods themselves.
Gale: Perhaps they deserve to be challenged. Perhaps you and I deserve better than to live and die as their pawns.
Gale: Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars?
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: I'm sure you're welcome.
Gale: There's that confidence I like.
Gale: I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening.
Gale: More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you.
Gale: Wyll's a good man. He may actually be a tried-and-true storybook hero.
Gale: Then again he's so full of himself it's a small miracle he hasn't resorted to self-cannibalism yet.
Gale: Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Wyll.
Gale: Indeed?
Gale: Perhaps that's a moment we ought to further explore.
Gale: Allow me to make the following proposition:
Gale: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen.
Gale: They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired.
Gale: The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself.
Gale: I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Leave it to you to woo someone with a book.
Gale: Forget the book then. Let's be blank slates on blank sheets, delightfully new.
Gale: What do you say?
Player: I'm afraid I have to decline.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there...
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - I wouldn't change it for the world.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: Another True Soul was looking for you. Nere - I aided him in the Underdark.
Balthazar: Ah, it was you who pulled his sorry carcass from the rubble. You should have left him there.
Balthazar: The miserable worm tried to kill me, hoping to take all the glory of this mission for himself.
Balthazar: Dull, dull, dull. Nere was never cut out to be a True Soul - he's a very obedient corpse, though.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: So you need my help - what would I have to do?
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Benji: *Sniff.* STINKS of CHEESE. *Sniff.* Between his PIGGY TOES.
Montgomery: How dare you! What in the hells is all of this?
Klaus: A necessity, good sir! The Steel Watch loves pretending sweet Rivington doesn't exist.
Klaus: So we have decided to protect you, dear patrons. No need to thank us. You'll be allowed in once I've done this batch - next!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: Is this extra security because of the priest who was murdered?
Klaus: Oh, more than him got the knife. They say the Absolute's cronies have been busy chopping people up like it's going out of style.
Klaus: They won't go near us, of course - Lucretious, Bringer of Night, protects us.
Klaus: And even the Absolute knows better than to tangle with a necromancer.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: I've never heard of an 'extraplanar circus'.
Klaus: We travel from plane to plane, thrilling all blessed to see us! From tempestuous djinni to belligerent redcaps - you'll find them all here.
Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!
Klaus: Hello, hello, and welcome to the Circus of the Last Days - the finest extraplanar circus there is!
Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Narrator: *This entire place practically vibrates with a familiar, excitable magic. You feel your patron giggle from afar - it's fey magic.*
Player: I never pass up a chance for a bit of faerie mischief - I'd like to enter.
Klaus: Not a problem, dear patron! Benji just has to check if you're a vicious murderer. Benji!
Benji: *Sniff.* Huh. *Sniff.* *SNIFF.*
Benji: Brain juice smells like PISS and IRON. NO. LIKE.
Klaus: That's a first. Usually I'd allow you in, but in these times I can take no chances. Move along - no circus for you.
Narrator: *You feel your patron bristle with a thousand briars at the rejection. It places some barbed words on your tongue - a weapon, should you need it.*
Player: I'm a friend of Lord Gortash. I wonder what he'll say if I tell him about this...

Gale: I finally have the tome I needed. Such knowledge - such power - contained in such a small object.
Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours?
Gale: Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: You 'think'? What happens if you fail?
Gale: Well, there'd be risk in such an endeavour, but only proportionate to the reward.
NodeContext: Doesn't want to get bogged down by doubts like these
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: And you believe yourself to be that successor?
Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm going to punish her - throughly.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Karlach: Pot, meet kettle.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I'm not a refugee.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Well, do you have the means to support yourself? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I can take care of myself. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Gauntlet Edwynna: Right. Article 30.1.5 of the Council's Decree on Extraordinary Wartime Measures. I am confiscating that. The city thanks you for your contribution.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Your name?
Player: My name is [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: Can I go now?
Gauntlet Edwynna: Not just yet.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Ravengard? More like the ghastliest tiefling south of Neverwinter.
Gauntlet Edwynna: I'm in no mood for jests. Business?
Player: I was born and raised in Baldur's Gate. This is my home.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.*
Narrator: *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.*
Narrator: *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.*
Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*
Narrator: *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.*
Narrator: *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mindmeld with steel watcher ends
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Gale: What's on your mind?
Player: Tell me a bit more about yourself.
Gale: Let's see. I hail from Waterdeep, the City of Splendours. I'm a wizard of considerable acclaim, and scholar of exceptional accomplishment.
Gale: I have a cat, a library, and a weakness for a good glass of wine. And if the mood takes me, I'm known to try my hand at poetry.
Gale: There.
Player: Go on...
Gale: Didn't that paint enough of a picture?
Player: Try peering into his mind. If he won't open up, you'll sneak in.
Narrator: *For a split second you see a swirl of untamed magic - then his defences drop like a portcullis.*
Gale: Out!
Gale: That was... uncalled for.
Player: You're right - I'm sorry. Curiosity got the better of me.
Gale: Not an eventuality I'm entirely unfamiliar with.
Gale: Nevertheless, please don't try that again unless I invite you to.
Gale: What's on your mind?

Gale: What's on your mind?
Player: Do you have much experience being a teacher of magic? I suspect so.
Gale: I've had a pupil or two, but never for very long. Their ineptitudes tend to... irk me.
Gale: You do seem to be a precocious talent though. I can always tell when I meet with a keen mind receptive to Mystra.
Gale: Keep it up and she might just take a personal interest in you one of these days.
Gale: What's on your mind?
