Gale: What's on your mind?
Player: So what did you think about what I pictured when we were connected by the Weave?
Gale: What did I think about an imaginary blow to the stomach?
Gale: Treating you to the real deal, that's what.
Gale: Why would you even bring this up? Come, let's go. I'm not in the mood for chatter.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: I had to watch my friends, people who can barely hold a sword, try to fight a pack of murderous zealots.
Alfira: All I could do was run.
Player: Only fools fight an ambush. Better to live and strike another day - preferably to the neck.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: It's a teahouse - hardly a lair.
Gandrel: A charming sight, to be sure. But the prettiest web still has a spider sitting at its centre.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: So I learned.
Gandrel: Ah - so you did. I thought you were just squinting from the stink.
Gandrel: But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: There's enough deception in this place - don't add to it.
Gandrel: It is not everyone who can see past her parlour tricks. As you wish - the truth is not mine to keep.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

Narrator: *You stand before the mysterious mace once more.*
Narrator: *A fist-sized piece of amber flecked with crimson is set in the handle, emitting a radiance all its own.*
Narrator: *This mace certainly has a very unusual design.*
Player: Reach into the light and take the mace.
Shadowheart: Not one to heed warnings then? We should leave that thing - it seems like trouble.
Narrator: *The glow around the mace sparkles with beautiful disaster.*
Narrator: *You recall all the measures meant to keep you from reaching this place.*
Narrator: *The brutal aches in your body yearn to take it, though you sense it will spell misfortune.*
Player: Take the mace anyway - what's the worst that could happen?

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.*
Narrator: *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Kneel before Vlaakith, your queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Karlach: Hey - wait! That's the only thing keeping us from transforming!
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Your kind is not known for trusting strangers. Quite rightly. Yet here you are.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: It is my greatest honour to obey.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me. And with a gith - I should have figured.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: You're infected, same as me. How did you get here?
Shadowheart: Quiet! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen.
Shadowheart: The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you.
Shadowheart: Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Lae'zel: The ravings of a lunatic. Strike her down.
Shadowheart: I'm tired of being pushed.
NodeContext: Shadowheart lunges towards the player with a knife.
Player: Stare her down.
Shadowheart: Don't look at me like that. I can't... no.
Shadowheart: Say what you have to say.
Player: Attack her.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I'm not the type to make a deal without the details. What exactly am I looking for?
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Player: I'll see what I can do.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I take what I'm due and I don't look back.
Alfira: That sounds quite freeing - but I don't have that option, I'm afraid.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.

Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.

Player: Another True Soul was looking for you. Nere - I aided him in the Underdark.

Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me. And with a gith - I should have figured.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: Hold up - who are you?
Shadowheart: Quiet! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen.
Shadowheart: The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you.
Shadowheart: Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood.
Shadowheart: I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Gale: Careful! She's about to lash out.
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Slow down - what whispering?
Shadowheart: They've been in my head ever since... it doesn't matter. They brought me here.
Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see.
Shadowheart: And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: You can't kill me just because some 'whispers' told you to.
Shadowheart: I can't see anything else! I can't shake it.
Shadowheart: The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: Threaten me again, and it'll be the last thing you do.

Shadowheart: What else do I do? My head is splitting open. I can't leave. I can't!
Player: Attack her.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Stop whispering - the guards'll notice.
Apprentice Laridda: We weren't whispering. Not us.
NodeContext: Tensing up
Lunkbug: We're working as we can. Very hard indeed.

Apprentice Laridda: Smokepowder? No, no - you misheard...

Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: A terrible situation. I'm sure you'll pay handsomely if I help.
Lunkbug: Found it in the ruins. It's all I've got. Please, just listen.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.*
Narrator: *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Wave politely.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player waves politely at Vlaakith.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The Inquisitor frowns at your insolence.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I expected little of istik education, but here we kneel before our queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith, unfazed in the least, considers you with critical interest.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Astarion: You're what? That is the only thing keeping us from a gruesome, tentacled-filled future.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Vlaakith: You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: Can't you kill the one inside yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Arabella: I don't know how. I'd kill 'em all if I could. I - I just want my mum and pops.
Arabella: We followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*

Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!

Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there...
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I don't complain constantly. It's very annoying.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: We already know the crown's dangerous. Wouldn't that make things worse?
Gale: Worse? It could be the best thing that ever happened to me. To us.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: This is no ordinary artefact, Gale. Do this and you'd challenge the gods themselves.
Gale: Perhaps they deserve to be challenged. Perhaps you and I deserve better than to live and die as their pawns.
Gale: Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars?
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Sarevok Anchev: A pleasing thing, to see these stones stained with the blood of those who disgraced my Father.
Sarevok Anchev: Our Father.
Sarevok Anchev: I know my like, child of Bhaal - but I needed to see you slaughter, first. To take life and revel in it.
Sarevok Anchev: Are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter, Orin?
Sarevok Anchev: But now, you have returned. Tell me, are you here to have your vengeance on my granddaughter?
Player: What do you mean - vengeance?
Sarevok Anchev: It is your right.
Sarevok Anchev: Orin only seeks the Bhaalian favour you were born to inherit.
Sarevok Anchev: She may have usurped you once, but all her rites and rituals will never match her to your natural gift.
Sarevok Anchev: Bhaal is about to name a new Chosen. All is between you and my granddaughter Orin now, and Orin has much to learn.
Sarevok Anchev: Our lord does not care for beauty. Bhaal cares only for death. Death in numbers. Death in droves.
Sarevok Anchev: It is a lesson Orin will only learn in death. I wonder if you will be the one to teach her?
Player: If you think she needs to be taught a lesson, why don't you teach her yourself?
Sarevok Anchev: We fought already. She bested me, humiliated me, enclosed me in this chamber with Bhaal's unending disappointment. I am a failure to Him.
Sarevok Anchev: But you - your blood is purer than mine ever was. He made you himself. The perfect killer.
Sarevok Anchev: I have heard of the duel Orin proposed to you. She seeks to sacrifice you in our Father's temple.
Sarevok Anchev: She dreams that your corpse will be her masterpiece, but she forgets - before your incident, you were the true master.
Sarevok Anchev: You were murder. Pure murder. No excesses. No pretentions.
Sarevok Anchev: I believe you will be the one to slay Orin.
Sarevok Anchev: But you will need my help.
Sarevok Anchev: I see you have not embraced your birthright yet. Perhaps with my stewardship,
Father will bless you yet.
Sarevok Anchev: And when he does, remember grandfather Sarevok. Remember how he helped you. Return to visit him, and tell the blood-drenched tale of your victory.
Sarevok Anchev: Before you may return to our Father's fold, I must first ensure that you remain as pure and worthy of his blessing as you once were.
Sarevok Anchev: So I ask -  why have you brought no offering, child of Bhaal? How am I to lead you in his worship, if you abstain from his most blessed sacrement?
Sarevok Anchev: Come, child of Murder, let me lead you in Bhaal's worship.
Player: I will make Bhaal proud.
Sarevok Anchev: You misunderstand the Lord of Murder. He is not proud. He simply is.
Sarevok Anchev: Let us begin.
Sarevok Anchev: Spirit of the slaughtered - return to us.
Sarevok Anchev: Show us the achievements this child has accomplished in thy unholy name.
Echo of Amelyssan: His will be done.
[description] NodeContext: Sarevok stands
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Sarevok reaches out his hand, and clenches it as though grasping something tight. He pulls the hand back towards himself, and a roiling, miasma of dark magic streams from off stage into a large cloud in front of the tribunal
[description] CinematicNodeContext: the cloud of dark energy clears. The spectre of our previous victim stands before the player. It is confused, scared, and tries to speak, but no noise escapes.
GROUP_Emperors: Can it be - Belynne herself, reduced to a spectre...
Sarevok Anchev: You took this spirit's life, and thus, its voice. So, speak for it. How was this pitiable creature slain?
Player: Slowly and painfully. I savoured every scream.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: 'The lady of this house'?
Gandrel: A more innocent name than some I could call her. But it is what she is that ought to concern you.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: Speak for yourself - I got what I wanted.
Gandrel: So said the fish 'round the hook in its mouth.
Gandrel: But, one fool to another, I can't say I judge you. The thing I hunt has slipped away from me.
Gandrel: If she can tell me how to flush him out, I'll pay whatever price she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: Who is it you're hunting?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Maybe I can help with your hunt.
Gandrel: No. This duty is mine alone. But for such an offer, an answer at least is owed.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: We've met - he's not the type to come quietly.
Gandrel: You do know him? I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: Tell him how to find your camp.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Shorter Appearance Sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.

Wyll: Shit.

Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.

Mizora: Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Let your father die. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: Tempting, but eradicating the brain may be wiser, to put an end to this madness.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: You may be right. I'll keep an open mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: That is all I ask. And remember, I know when your mind is closed.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To watch them suffer - I need no other reason than that.

Astarion: Morning. I hope last night's little unpleasantness hasn't left a bad taste in your-
Astarion: Well. I hope there are no bad feelings.
Player: You're lucky I didn't kill you.
Astarion: And you're lucky I'm not a 'true' vampire. Last night could have gone very differently if I'd magically summoned a pack of wolves.
Astarion: Alas, I'm just a spawn. All of the hunger, few of the powers.
Player: Pity. I thought you'd be more powerful.
Astarion: I wouldn't say that. Even the most powerful vampires in history couldn't survive in the sun, but it seems I can.
Astarion: Someone - or something - wants me alive. They've changed the rules.
Astarion: Standing in the sun, wading through a river, wandering into homes without an invitation - they're all perfectly mundane activities now.
Astarion: As for my other quirks - well, we can figure those out in time.
Player: If I can help, just ask. We're in this together.
Astarion: Oh you're such a sweetheart.
Astarion: I'm just glad you're being sensible about these revelations. I was worried people might turn up with torches and pitchforks.
Astarion: Although there's still time.
NodeContext: Looks over his shoulder, realising someone's approaching

Karlach: No sense judging someone for who they are. Except devils, obviously.
Gale: A word of warning, Astarion: I taste absolutely awful.
Gale: Oh, and a quick word of warning, Astarion: I taste absolutely awful. Keep your distance.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: A design you could follow?
Gale: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours?
Gale: Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.
Gale: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present.
Gale: If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: And you think Mystra will let you do this?
Gale: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Stay silent.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: This is no ordinary artefact, Gale. Do this and you'd challenge the gods themselves.
Gale: Perhaps they deserve to be challenged. Perhaps you and I deserve better than to live and die as their pawns.
Gale: Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars?
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I had Z'rell's permission - that good enough for you?
Balthazar: Z'rell exceeds her authority. But fine, I'll overlook your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The party enters camp.
Vlaakith: Raise your eyes. Look upon She Who Conquers.

Vlaakith: And you - you are abominations twice over. You carry ghaik parasites. And you harbour the Heretic Prince Orpheus.
Lae'zel: Queen Vlaakith - tsk'va!

Vlaakith: The betrayer Voss LIES!
Vlaakith: Hear my words, vin'iisk.
Vlaakith: The traitor Voss has lied to you. The Heretic Prince would shatter us in an instant. The Great Dominion, shrunk to the head of a pin.
Narrator: *Can this be true? Is the githyanki prince really a threat to his own people or simply a challenge to Vlaakith's rule?*

Vlaakith: Return to the Astral Prism. Slay Orpheus the pretender.
Vlaakith: Serve me and I will ascend you. You will be no mere warrior, nor kith'rak. You will be Baht t'Vlaakith.
Vlaakith: Commander of Dragons. My only, my Chosen.

Vlaakith: Do not fail me. For you would not survive the flood to follow.

Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: What are you proposing?
Mizora: A life for a life. No contract is ended without sacrifice. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.

Gale: Thank you.
NodeContext: You look at the player with a big smile and the words are warm and heartfelt.
Player: Spontaneous thank-yous make me suspicious.
Gale: Come now! This is a night for celebration, not suspicion.
Gale: I thank you for seeking me out. Amidst all this merriment I wasn't sure we'd have a chance to speak this evening.
Gale: More's the pity you've already found someone else to make merry with, just the two of you.
Gale: There's something... unspeakable about Shadowheart. But I mean that in a good way. She seems to me like a bud on the cusp of bursting into a rose.
Gale: That or deadly nightshade.
Gale: Far be it from me of course, to question your tastes.
Player: Actually, I may just want to spend the night with you instead of Lae'zel.
Gale: Indeed?
Gale: We had a moment, you and I, a moment in which we expressed the possibility of becoming more than friends.
Gale: Tonight seems perfectly suited for such endeavours.
Gale: Allow me to make the following proposition:
Gale: There's a book that circulates in Amn, detailing the first thousand nights of a newlywed king and queen.
Gale: They turned everything they did into an art. The art of conversation. The art of taste, time honoured and newly acquired.
Gale: The art of the body. The exploration and acceptance of the self and the other. The art of the night itself.
Gale: I say we take a page from their book.
Player: Let me stop you right there. That's not something I'm interested in.
Gale: Too bad. One should never be afraid to live life to the fullest.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: I'm trying my best to be...
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.

Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?

Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: The design for self-destruction, more like. Didn't this crown kill Karsus?
Gale: Not exactly. It was what he did with it that sealed his fate, and for a time, that of magic itself. The Crown was merely the means.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.
Gale: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: I thought you were past this kind of temptation, Gale. You know exactly where such over-reaching leads.
Gale: Neither of us can know what truly may be if we don't at least try. Potential is nothing in itself - just a fleeting dream, unless we drag it into the waking world. Please, at least think on it.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Lae'zel: My queen.

Narrator: *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*

Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.*
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: What are the properties of this relic, magical or otherwise? So I can be of better assistance, of course.
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.

Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: 'The lady of this house'?
Gandrel: A more innocent name than some I could call her. But it is what she is that ought to concern you.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: I know Ethel - that sounds nothing like her.
Gandrel: I hope this Ethel is waiting for you when you walk through that door. But I suspect you'll find something else.
Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: I like danger. The truth - now.
Gandrel: Perhaps I was... hasty with my words.

Gandrel: Perhaps you could tell me where to look, and I could ensure peace of mind for us both?
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?

Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here.
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me.
Player: Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him...
Balthazar: ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: Jobs like this always go smoother when I know exactly what I'm looking for.
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.

Arabella: Mm. Maybe. But you gotta help me first.

Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.

Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm.
Arabella: Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll think about it. My hands are full with these cultists.
Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: I've rarely seen corpses as violated as theirs are - it was quite the sight.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?

Arabella: To the hells with your camp, and to the hells with you.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: The design for self-destruction, more like. Didn't this crown kill Karsus?
Gale: Not exactly. It was what he did with it that sealed his fate, and for a time, that of magic itself. The Crown was merely the means.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: To what end?
Gale: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Don't dare to assume why I worship. Not all of us share such transactional relationships with our gods.
Gale: But do you not expect something in return for your devotion? Some favour, some stir of courage, some response?
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.
Gale: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.
Gale: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first.

Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.

Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.

Zevlor: We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.

Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I am here in the honour of justice and order - that is all.
He Who Was: Then steel your heart - for this woman is a serpent who wears many faces. Do not be fooled.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.

Wyll: Not as if you can relate to the killing urge, can you? Hmph - I can taste the hypocrisy from here.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Yours is a classic tale of cowardice. Were you a character in a tale of mine, I would kill you off - immediately.
Player: You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.

Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.

Gandrel: Today? The same as you - a humble supplicant, come to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Not at all. I was invited for tea.
Gandrel: Of course - as the spider invites the fly. You need something, I expect. And she sensed it.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: I know Ethel - that sounds nothing like her.
Gandrel: I hope this Ethel is waiting for you when you walk through that door. But I suspect you'll find something else.
Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.

Player: Of course - a child is in danger. I will do what I can.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: A githyanki? What are you doing down here?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Don't worry - I'm not here to judge.
Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I try to be. For I serve a greater power - one who embodies everything good in this world.
Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The code of Bahamut. His guidance leads me in all things.
Ptaris: Do you really believe that? You are unfit to say his name.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I never should have saved you. But I'm happy to rectify my mistake.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.
