He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm here to make sure she sees justice.
He Who Was: There is no justice for traitors - only pain.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: It's all right, I'm not here to judge you.
Madeline: You're - you're not? But he said I deserved it. That I'm... evil.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: There's nothing you need do. This wasn't your fault - I promise.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon‚Äôs voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human‚Äôs belly, but it‚Äôs a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am no student, I seek knowledge of the curse. It is a blight on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: Well - it won't stain this beautiful city with its abominations - not anymore.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Wulbren, enough. The Gondians are no more - I am all that is left. You've won.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: I will be long gone from this wretched city before that happens. I am no threat - I am... nothing.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: You carry the light and love of all that is good, Barcus. I think you would make an excellent leader of the Ironhands, don't you?
Player: Perhaps the Ironhand Gnomes need a new leader. What say you, Barcus?

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what‚Äôs inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha was swayed by Shadow Druids. She nearly sealed the grove.
Halsin: Kagha... I should have suspected she'd take things too far. I'll deal with her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.
Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise.
Halsin: Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: Having a shapeshifting bear-druid at my side might make things easier.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Come with me.
Halsin: So be it. May Silvanus lend us nature's fury.

Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
Zevlor: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.
Zevlor: And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things.
Zevlor: We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things.
Zevlor: We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Fezzerk: Look what we got here - another little birdie wantin' to fly!
NodeContext: Cruel bravado.The goblin sees the player approach and boldly announces it to his cronies - he thinks some fresh victims have just turned up.
Fezzerk: Yehehueh! Flap those wings some more, an' I'll feed you a worm!
NodeContext: Greatly amused. A schoolyard bully tormenting the little kid. Projecting his voice a little (Fezzerk calls out to taunt his deep gnome prisoner, who rotates on the sail of a windmill a short-moderate distance off.)
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: An' you - hope you got a stomach fer heights!
NodeContext: Confident, unpleasant. Turning his attention to the player to deliver a threat.
Player: I won't interfere. I just want to pass by.
Fezzerk: Heh, funny. That's what our birdie wanted.
NodeContext: Mocking.
Barcus Wroot: ...Release me this instant, you beasts!
NodeContext: Panicked, angry. Issuing an ultimatum even though he has no means of following through on it.
Fezzerk: 'Less you wanna join him up there, you'd best pay the toll.
NodeContext: Fezzerk mockingly refers to the deep gnome's predicament as he threatens the player. 'Passing by' refers to rotating on a windmill rather than safe passage through the area, in his book.
Fezzerk: Cough it up! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
NodeContext: Fezzerk declares his price. (A ridiculously high sum - questionable whether he truly knows how absurd a demand this is)
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Here's my counter-offer: you can all live so long as you leave right now.
Player: I can pay twice that much. I just have to go and fetch it.
Fezzerk: A haggler, are ya? How 'bout this: you live...
NodeContext: A dimwit bully who thinks he's shrewd operator.
Fezzerk: ...an' pay me loads more! Yeuheuheu! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
Fezzerk: How do you like that? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])
Player: I've changed my mind - release the gnome and clear off. Or else.
Fezzerk: Or else what, you'll fight us? Bit late to find some backbone, don't you reckon?
Fezzerk: You want this little cave-lurkin' wotsit?
Fezzerk: Find your own! He's ours!
Narrator: *A strange symbol glows, marked on their flesh, and something within you stirs in response.*
Player: You will release the gnome. That's an order.
Fezzerk: I... yes. Whatever you want.
Narrator: *The presence deep in your mind is awake, unblinking. This is it. A single word pervades your consciousness: 'Soon'.*
Narrator: *The goblin's nostrils flare nervously. All of his bluster seems to vanish.*
Fezzerk: We're leaving.
Goblin Devout: What about the gnome? Ain't we s'posed to bring him to -
Fezzerk: I said we're leaving!
Fezzerk: Apologies, your grace. We didn't mean to doubt a True Soul. We'll be off.

Angry Mar'hyah: You again?
Angry Mar'hyah: You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods.
Angry Mar'hyah: Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.
Player: Sorry.
Angry Mar'hyah: It's fine. I have a very robust sense of humour.
Angry Mar'hyah: What do you want?
Angry Mar'hyah: You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Whistle for Scratch.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Dog approaches player
Oyster Boy Dringo: Scratch! It's good to see you boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut up, Dringo. And get back to work!
Angry Mar'hyah: And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: This dog is property of Sword Coast Couriers. I'll take him off your hands now.
Player: He lives with me - you can't just take him.
Angry Mar'hyah: I can do whatever I please - he's my dog. Now get out - this is a private yard.
Player: This noble beast has tasted true freedom - he will never be brought to heel again.
Angry Mar'hyah: I'm not surprised. Gomwick always indulged him. And he's got a spark in his eye I don't like - looks lively.

Wyll: Go on. Give me your best shot.

NodeContext: Wyll holding is holding a sword with his RIGHT hand.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll turns to you, smiling.

Narrator: *The man's smile bends downward, and his thoughts become yours.*
Narrator: *You are the Blade of Frontiers, racing through the wastes of Avernus. Just ahead, a diabolical figure - red skin, single curled horn - blazes with flame, bloodied greataxe held high.*
Narrator: *It's Karlach - the woman you met in the wilds.*

Player: I can help you hunt that devil of yours.

Wyll: Still - when the time comes, call for the Blade. I won't be long to answer.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: A githyanki? What are you doing down here?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Was Lady Esther bad too?
Ptaris: She did not have the strength to be good. She was another like father - lacking in moral fibre.
NodeContext: Indifferent to the dead body at his feet.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: I follow my gut. That's all anyone can do.
Ptaris: Your gut cannot be trusted. That is why the code exists. That is why you failed.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I wield my anger like a blade, but it does not rule me. I am no more 'bad' than you are.
Ptaris: You mean anger is not always bad? But - but that's not what father said.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm going to punish her - throughly.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: By the light of the one I serve, I forgive you. This wasn't your doing.

Karlach: Ah! A circus! Can we go?!
Player: Is now the time for a circus? The army of the Absolute is close.

Klaus: The Absolute's little murderers wouldn't dare.

Klaus: Benji here checks all our patrons to make sure none of you are vicious murderers. Can't be too careful!

Player: I'm not a threat to you or anyone else in the circus - I swear it.

Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew.
Zevlor: We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer.
Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Ptaris: Who are you? Another who needs to learn the difference between right and wrong?

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the cr√®che?*
Player: What is this place?
Ptaris: It is my home, of course. Father raised me here. Taught me. Made me grow.
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: What did they do that was so terrible?
Ptaris: They did not live up to father's code. Even he did not follow it correctly.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I try not to look at things as good or evil. Life is a mixture of both.
Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: I follow my gut. That's all anyone can do.
Ptaris: Your gut cannot be trusted. That is why the code exists. That is why you failed.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: Ungrateful yank. Our kin would have destroyed you if it wasn't for me.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: Playing with the dead, are we? How charming.
He Who Was: Indeed. One whose secrets are not for your ears. Be on your way.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Death often comes for a reason. I've killed before, does that make me a murderer?
He Who Was: Depends. Did those you kill trust you? Care for you?
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: What good is murder if it isn't done in the name of the divine? It would be an honour to punish her.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Hardly a fair trial - you've already decided her guilt. Why?
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon‚Äôs voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human‚Äôs belly, but it‚Äôs a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Forgetfulness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Gandrel: Ah, a fellow wanderer. Forgive the aroma.
Narrator: *You catch a waft of something foul - metallic and sickly-sweet.*
Gandrel: Powdered iron-vine. Most monsters will think twice before making a meal of me.
Gandrel: An old hunter's trick - if you can't mask your scent, spoil it.
Player: You're a monster hunter? Not what I imagined.
Gandrel: Hah. Perhaps that is why I have survived so long where more fearsome peers have not.
Gandrel: You would be wise to look past the seeming of things, if you intend to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: A sharp wit will serve you better, if you're to bargain with the lady of this house.
Gandrel: That is why you come to her lair, I take it? To bargain?
Player: Are you talking about Auntie Ethel?
Gandrel: A gentle name. But I speak of her nature.
Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.
Player: What price is that?
Gandrel: Whatever's easiest to lose and hardest to do without.
Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.
Player: I'd advise against helping such a creature thrive. What quarry could be worth that price?
Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.
Player: Your coyness is getting boring. Tell me.
Gandrel: You take insult where none is intended, my friend. But fine - I won't add to it.
Gandrel: I hunt a vampire spawn called Astarion. I'm bound to bring him back to Baldur's Gate - alive.
Gandrel: Though I cannot swear to his condition once my tribe are done with him. Is he known to you?
Player: You can give up your hunt. Astarion's under my protection.
Gandrel: ...I see. Your loyalty is admirable but misplaced. His kind have charm beyond our mortal means to resist.
Gandrel: I can show you who he truly is - if you will just tell me where to find him.
Gandrel: But you're right - he's no true vampire. Not yet. I don't suppose you'll tell me where he is?
Player: I'm not going to help you find him. Back off.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.

Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
Zevlor: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.
Zevlor: And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: Should've stayed in the Hells - our kind might be treated better there.
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded.
Zevlor: But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Player: 'The Descent'? What is that?
Zevlor: I'm surprised you haven't heard of it.
Zevlor: The High Overseer - our grand protector - signed a pact with devils. It dragged Elturel straight to Hell.
Zevlor: Lucky for us, a group of adventurers found a way to bring the city back.
Zevlor: Afterwards, people looked at us and just saw 'devilkin'. No different from the druids here, really.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.
Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Wyll: Hells' great fires - you were on the ship.

Wyll: I'm sure you know the stories. Doomed to shed our skin and become illithid. They say there's no coming back.
Wyll: But we haven't sprouted any tentacles - not yet, anyway. Could just be good luck. I'm not so...

Wyll: Her name is Karlach. An archdevil's soldier I swore on my good eye to kill.
Wyll: I tracked her through the Hells to the mind flayer ship. But the damned illithids infected me before I could end her.
Wyll: She's out there now, preying on the innocent. I don't kill her, she'll leave behind nothing but a trail of corpses.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Havkelaag: A series of moral imperatives bestowed by the great dragon-deity Bahamut.
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.

Shadowheart: There's nothing more for us to do here - not until we complete Lady Shar's trials.
Player: What are these trials, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: I'm sorry I kept it from you. It's not a secret to be shared lightly.
Shadowheart: The Dark Justiciars were the Nightsinger's most trusted warriors - this is where they earned their place.
Shadowheart: In order to join Lady Shar's elite, you had to pass her trials, then make a sacrifice in her innermost sanctum - one revealed only when you've proven yourself. Very few made it that far.
Shadowheart: I've dreamed of this place. This is my destiny - I must complete the trials.

Gandrel: Her kind have hidden among us since the first darkness - and their knowledge is matched only by their spite.
Gandrel: Know how to ask, and they'll share that knowledge. If you're fool enough to pay their price.

Gandrel: But the thing I hunt has gone to ground. If she can tell me how to draw him out, I'll pay whatever she asks.
Gandrel: But she thrives on suffering. Once she hears what awaits my quarry when I catch him, she will help.

Gandrel: Truth is like a blade, my friend. We can arm ourselves with it.
Gandrel: Or just as easily find it pressed against our throat. I would not put you in danger.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Sounds, er, fun.
Gale: Not everyone is comfortable being alone with their thoughts. Though I never felt alone with a book in my hand. Or with her for company.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. An expression you both share - when she gives in to her more feline qualities, a mouse trapped beneath her paw...
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: So I remind you of your pet? How romantic...
Gale: I assure you, were you to meet Tara you would see the comparison for the flattery it is. But perhaps that's not a point worth labouring further.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Being mentioned in the same breath as your pet isn't the compliment you think it is...
Gale: Then let me say it more plainly -
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: The feeling's mutual - you're a wonderful friend. Though usually more... erudite.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: You've never seen another githyanki before?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Ptaris: It is honour. Justice. The true form of goodness we all must live by, decreed by Bahamut himself.
Ptaris: You are not capable of following its teachings.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: You feel strange, don't you? That's your conscience. It's telling you to stop.
Ptaris: My - my what?

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face.
Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?

Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.

Player: You serve your oath to the Zhent impressively, but I'm afraid I'll be taking that cargo. Now.
Player: No. This is the point where I stop asking, and start cutting.
Rugan: Fine - no need for more violence. I'll tell my associates everything was lost in the ambush.

Rugan: And no hard feelings, y'hear? I'd have done the same if I were you. Business at the end of a blade is still business.
Rugan: Crafty swine like you could make a name for yourself in the Zhentarim. Make sure to drop by our hideout.
Rugan: Pass phrase at the door is 'little serpent, long shadow'. I'll tell my associates to expect you.
Player: I already met your friends - we didn't get along too well.
Rugan: And yet here you are. There's not many cause trouble in a Zhent hideout and walk away.
Rugan: I'd rather walk away too. So let's say our goodbyes, and speak no more of it.
Player: You can leave - but your cargo stays.

Halsin: Nature's blessings. Are you ready to do what is necessary?
Player: Tell me what you know about Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Travelling to Moonrise is no small task. Expect dangers like you've never seen before.
Player: I'm something of an expert when it comes to imperilling myself.
Halsin: This is different. There's more fingers on a hand than there are survivors of that place.
Player: What's so dangerous about it?
Halsin: To get to the Towers, you'll need to pass through a terrible place - a cursed place.
Halsin: This curse shrouds everything in shadow - you will not find life, light, or anything natural there.
Halsin: Any who linger are twisted by the curse; they become shadow beings - tormented, dangerous souls.
Player: The Absolute's forces can tolerate such a place?
Halsin: So it seems, though I don't know how. You will have to choose your approach carefully.
Halsin: You could go overland - along the Risen Road or through the mountains. Easier at first, but you'll run into the shadow curse eventually.
Halsin: You could also go under. There is a tunnel somewhere in this very temple of Sel√ªne. It leads to Moonrise Towers through the Underdark.
Halsin: Long ago, a man called Ketheric Thorm built a secret stronghold deep down there, before rallying a whole army of Dark Justiciars - Shar worshippers.
Shadowheart: Sounds rather ingenious.
Halsin: Aradin and his lot were looking for a way down there - they were promised riches if they retrieved a relic called the Nightsong. But I think there's more.
Halsin: From this stronghold, Ketheric's forces could access both the temple of Sel√ªne and Moonrise Towers - but he was defeated before he could launch an attack.
Halsin: If you can find this place, I'll wager it will reveal a more direct path to Moonrise Towers, and may bypass the worst of the shadow curse.
Player: I already found the place you're talking about - it's called Grymforge.
Halsin: You've already been? Impressive. You'll make me redundant at this rate. What did you find?
Player: Absolute followers - but that's about all.
Halsin: Keep looking. If they're present, then it's likely there's a route to Moonrise somewhere.
Halsin: It may prove impossible to avoid the shadow curse entirely, but if you find any way to limit your exposure, seize it.
Halsin: You may reconsider once you see the effects of the curse for yourself.
Player: I may live to regret this - or maybe I won't - but fine, I'll help you save the grove first.
Halsin: You will? Oak Father bless you. I'll be in your debt twice over if we succeed.
Halsin: You know what's needed - the deaths of Dror Ragzlin, the drow Minthara, and the priestess, Gut. May nature guide you.
Halsin: I could come and help you... but be warned - I won't be able to suppress my animal side. Subtlety will not be an option.
Halsin: If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Come with me.
Halsin: So be it. May Silvanus lend us nature's fury.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon‚Äôs voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human‚Äôs belly, but it‚Äôs a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Withers: Hast thou seen the futility of thy actions?
Player: Sorry. I was a bit quick on the draw there.
Withers: An apology to one such as myself is but empty air.
Withers: Dost thou need my services?
Player: Not to be rude, but what are you?
Withers: There are many answers to that question. None are important.
Player: Skeletons aren't supposed to be able to talk.
Withers: Correct.
Player: Are you going to explain further?
Withers: No.
Withers: No.
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing?
Player: Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: You mentioned a cost - what is it?
Withers: A matter of coin. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: At least that's straightforward. I want to resurrect someone.
Withers: Very well. Speak their name and it shall be done.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_3_56966d5e-534d-4930-264e-050a2345db3d].
Player: Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: Please bring back Gale. I can't live with what I did.
Withers: Thou didst not kill thine own friend. Thou offered thy friend as sacrifice.
Withers: Their soul is in a place even I cannot peer into. A place no soul should venture.
Withers: Death alone was not suffering enough for thine Urge. Thou shouldst fear thyself.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I need to resurrect someone.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.
Player: I want to resurrect [CAMP_Jergal_PlayerToResurrect_3_56966d5e-534d-4930-264e-050a2345db3d].
Player: Here's the gold.

Gale: A beautiful night, don't you think? Nothing like a brush with destruction to make one appreciate the majesty of the celestial canvas.
Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: I hope you aren't talking about Mystra again...
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. You share her pragmatic streak.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: So I remind you of your pet? How romantic...
Gale: I assure you, were you to meet Tara you would see the comparison for the flattery it is. But perhaps that's not a point worth labouring further.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: I'm flattered. Is your good opinion so hard to come by?
Gale: One doesn't become the most powerful archmage in Waterdeep and lover to the goddess of magic herself by having low standards.
Gale: I assure you, when I tell someone they're wonderful - I mean it. And you are wonderful.
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: I see. Then perhaps we see each other in the same light after all. A resplendent one, flush with warmth and anticipation, but one which I must shy away from, for now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale
Gale: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.
Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus - I believe I mentioned him before. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: We already know the crown's dangerous. Wouldn't that make things worse?
Gale: Worse? It could be the best thing that ever happened to me. To us.
Gale: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.
Gale: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.
Player: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.
Gale: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned.
Gale: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.
Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.
Gale: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.
Player: I thought you were past this kind of temptation, Gale. You know exactly where such over-reaching leads.
Gale: Neither of us can know what truly may be if we don't at least try. Potential is nothing in itself - just a fleeting dream, unless we drag it into the waking world. Please, at least think on it.
Gale: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.
Gale: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.
Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.
Player: Mystra is no friend of the Dark Lady. If you can dethrone her, you have my support.

Gale: Even in such fraught times as these, there is peace to be found in the stillness as evening draws in.
Gale: I used to while away many hours just like these with my companion, though in far comfier surrounds.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Sounds, er, fun.
Gale: Not everyone is comfortable being alone with their thoughts. Though I never felt alone with a book in my hand. Or with her for company.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be most impressed by our efforts saving these tieflings. Proud, even. And I've given her little to be proud of recently.
Gale: After I was afflicted with my condition, I locked myself in my tower for an entire year. I was inconsolable, wallowing in my self-inflicted tragedy.
Gale: I'd given up on myself, but Tara never did. It was her encouragement, her research that led me to my treatment. Once we knew that magically-infused items were the key, she went out to find them for me. She saved my life.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: She must be very smart, to have done all that.
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. Something in the way you roll your eyes when I speak...
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: She sounds like a fine animal. One I'd be honoured to know.
Gale: She'll love you. So long as you don't rub her belly. She hates it when anyone does that.
Player: Not as much as I hate talking about cats. Is there nothing else on your mind?
Gale: Not an animal lover? Nobody's perfect, I suppose.
Gale: Nonetheless, your finer qualities are remarkably plentiful.
Gale: Suffice it to say, I think rather a lot of you. And there aren't many on this plane who I'd give such high praise.
Player: Being mentioned in the same breath as your pet isn't the compliment you think it is...
Gale: Then let me say it more plainly -
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: You know what, I think I've clearly had far too much wine. And you've had nowhere near enough. I think this is a conversation best held back on - for now.

Gale: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.
Gale: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
Gale: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
Player: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.

Gale: It's a view I would once have shared with my companion. Though definitely unaccompanied by such revelry.
Gale: She preferred it when we were alone, curled up before a crackling hearth with some ancient, esoteric tome between us, ink glinting in the firelight...
Player: Are you... are you talking about your cat?
Gale: By Ahghairon's lost nose - no!
Gale: Tara is not any cat. She's a tressym. And given your confusion, I'm guessing you've never met one. They're brilliant creatures - fine company for any self-respecting wizard.
Gale: I speak of Tara, my tressym, assistant, my constant companion through all the ills and tribulations my hubris has thrust upon me.
Gale: She'd be proud to see me keeping such fine company - the saviour of those poor tieflings, no less. And I've given her precious little to be proud of recently.
Gale: She has a good heart, and she would recognise the same in your actions here. I'm sure she'd approve of me lending myself to your efforts.
Gale: After so long being cared for by someone else, it feels good to have repaid the favour. Not directly to Tara, but to these poor tieflings. I'm sure she would approve.
Player: What is Tara like?
Gale: 'Smart' does her a disservice. She's a fine wizard in her own right, though somewhat held back by her lack of opposable thumbs.
Gale: You remind me of her somewhat. There's a steeliness to you, an unwavering tenacity even in the face of, to be frank, quite dire odds.
Gale: I wish she were here for me to make a formal introduction, but I would never ask her to undertake such a journey. She is safer at home.
Gale: Besides, she was always telling me I needed to spread my wings, so to speak. Find mortal friends, instead of hanging onto Mystra's coattails. So that's what I'm doing. I hope.
Player: You don't have any friends?
Gale: Sadly not. If I'm being entirely honest, my social circle is rather small. More of a dot. Or a pinhead.
Gale: I've got aquaintances, certainly. Plenty of colleagues. But friends? Those are precious indeed.
Gale: I hope, though we've only known each other for a short time, I might be able to count you among that number?
Player: Friends with the mighty Gale of Waterdeep? I'd be honoured.
Gale: I'm glad. To know you enjoy my company is, well, it's rather wonderful actually. I'd be loathe to waste the time of someone who's become rather important to me.
Gale: I think you're rather wonderful. And that's not a word I waste on anyone unworthy of it.
Player: Actually, I was thinking we'd be wonderful together...
Gale: Wait. Are you saying...
Gale: I see. Then perhaps we see each other in the same light after all. A resplendent one, flush with warmth and anticipation, but one which I must shy away from, for now.

Gale: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
Player: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...
Gale: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.
Gale: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.
Gale: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.
Gale: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.
Gale: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
Player: You 'think'? What happens if you fail?
Gale: Well, there'd be risk in such an endeavour, but only proportionate to the reward.

Gale: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.

Gale: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.

Gale: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.

Gale: Astra navigabimus.

Gale: Few mortals ever glimpse what you're about to see. But don't be alarmed - I'm here with you. Now... open your eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Fade up from black as the player opens their eyes to a dazzling spectacle. They and Gale are now sitting in a small boat that shimmers with iridescent light. Unpiloted, it silently meanders through a majestic, infinite starfield.
Gale: The Outer Planes. This is where gods dwell. Where they observe us from afar. Where they make play-things of us.
Gale: They would keep all of this from us - the power, the possibilities. They only want us to serve them, pray to them... and ultimately, die for them.
Gale: But what if we didn't need them? What if we wielded their power instead, and helped ourselves in all the ways they refuse to. I could make that happen. I could make this illusion a reality, with you by my side.
Player: You know how I feel. I've already voiced my support.
Gale: Yes, you have. But I want more than your support. I want your heart.
Gale: The tadpoles, the orb - these threats to our existence - the gods could aid us if they wished, but instead they cower behind Ao. So let us act ourselves.

Gale: With the power of the crown, any foe would be rendered impotent. Any obstacle would be dwarfed by our might.
Gale: I used to believe Mystra's forgiveness was worth dying for. But I was wrong. You showed me just how much I have to live for.
Gale: With you, I forget my goddess. I love you.
Gale: Tell me you feel the same way. Tell me you want what I want. Please.

Gale: You mean... you want the same as I do?
